Father Emil Kapaun was born in Pilsen, KS and served as an Army Chaplain. During the Korean War, Fr. Kapaun was taken as a Prisoner of War. He continued serving and ministering to his fellow POWs until his death. In 2013 Chaplain Kapaun was awarded the Medal of Honor posthumously

I am pleased to learn that Chaplain Kapaun‚Äôs remains were identified as part of the ongoing Defense POW/MIA Accounting Agency‚Äôs Korean War Disinterment Project. However, in my last term, House Republicans offered Motions to Recommit in bad faith, to force ‚Äúgotcha‚Äù votes. This year, House rules were changed so that MTRs send bills back to the committees they originate from‚Äîdelaying votes or killing bills entirely.

The minority party can offer a Motion to Recommit just before we vote on final passage of a bill. If the MTR is adopted, the text of the bill is revised. Historically, MTRs were offered by Members ‚Äúfriendly‚Äù to the bill, as a way to correct errors in the text.

When I ran for Congress, I made a promise to be transparent about the major decisions I make as Representative for California‚Äôs 45th District. So, I‚Äôd like to explain ‚ÄúMotions to Recommit‚Äù (MTRs) and my recent decision to uniformly vote NO on all of them. [THREAD]

Vanita Gupta's plan to get rid of qualified immunity would punish good law enforcement officers and make us all less safe. 

Another reason why she needs to be rejected.

Few officers would continue policing if, any time they arrest a criminal, they could face protracted litigation. 

If Vanita Gupta has her way, a wealthy drug trafficker could harass a police officer by hiring attorneys to file frivolous lawsuits.
But without qualified immunity, our court systems would be flooded with frivolous litigation designed to intimidate, impede, and financially harass police officers.
Police can be and routinely are held accountable when they engage in misconduct. They can face criminal prosecution, workplace discipline, and personal liability when they violate clear rights.
